description: Options supported by Circuitscape config.ini files

compress_grids.name: Compress output grids
compress_grids.description: Output ASCII grids are automatically compressed using the gzip file format. This can be useful when many large maps will be written.

connect_four_neighbors_only.name: Connect four neighbors only
connect_four_neighbors_only.description: Connect raster cells to FOUR neighbors instead of EIGHT

connect_using_avg_resistances.name: Connect using average resistance
connect_using_avg_resistances.description: Use average resistance instead of conductance for connections between cells

data_type.name: Data type
data_type.description: Will you be analyzing raster or network data?

ground_file.name: Ground file
ground_file.description: This file specifies locations of ground nodes and resistances or conductances of resistors tying them to ground. Either a raster or a text list may be used. Rasters must have the same cell size, projection, and extent as the resistance grid, and cells that do not contain grounds should be coded with NODATA values. Note that if a direct (R = 0) ground connection conflicts with a current source, the ground will be removed unless the 'remove source' option in the Options Window is chosen.

habitat_map_is_resistances.name: Habitat map is resistances
habitat_map_is_resistances.description: Input map represents resistances instead of conductances?

included_pairs_file.name: Included pairs file
included_pairs_file.description: This option allows users to only perform calculations on a subset of focal node pairs. Users can either identify pairs to include in calculations, or pairs to exclude, as specified in the first line of the file.This affects all modes except the Advanced Mode. Files should be in tab-delimited text with a .txt extension.

log_transform_maps.name: Log transform current maps
log_transform_maps.description: Values in output current maps will reflect a log10 transform of current densities, which can be useful for visualizing them in some GIS packages (e.g., ArcView 3.X). Cells with zero current will be re-coded with NODATA values.

mask_file.name: Raster mask file
mask_file.description: Cells with negative, zero, or NODATA values in the mask will be dropped from the corresponding resistance map (i.e., treated as complete barriers). Positive integer cells will be retained. File should only contain integers and be in raster format

max_parallel.name: Max parallel
max_parallel.description: Choose how many processors you would like to devote to Circuitscape runs.

output_file.name: Base output file name (should end with .out)
output_file.description: Choose a directory path and base file name for output files. Resistances, current maps, voltage maps, and configuration files (which save user interface settings and have a .ini extension) will all use this base name, along with appropriate suffixes and extensions.

point_file.name: Point file
point_file.description: This file specifies locations of nodes between which effective resistance and current flow are to be calculated. Each focal node should have a unique positive integer ID. Files may be text lists specifying coordinates or appropriate raster grid formats. When a grid is used, it must have the same cell size and extent as the resistance grid. The value stored in each grid cell location refers to the focal node ID. Cells that do not contain focal nodes should be coded with NODATA values. When a text list is used, the value field references the focal node ID.  For raster analyses, focal nodes may occur at points (single cells on the resistance grid) or across regions (Fig. 8). For the latter, a single ID would occupymore than one cell in a grid or more than one pair of coordinates in a text list (and falling within more than one cell in the underlying resistance grid). Cells within a single region would then be collapsed into a single node, as they are when short-circuit region files are used (see below). The difference is that a focal region will be 'burned in' to the resistance grid only for pairwise calculations that include that focal node. As with short-circuit regions, focal regions need not be made up of contiguous cells. For large grids or large numbers of focal nodes, focal regions may require more computation time. When calculating resistances on large raster grids and not creating voltage or current maps, focal points will run much more quickly.

polygon_file.name: Short-circuit region file
polygon_file.description: Short-circuit regions act as areas of zero resistance, essentially providing patches through which current is given a 'free ride' as it flows across the landscape. Each short-circuit region should have a unique positive integer identifier; cells within each region are merged into a single node with all other cells in the region, including non-adjacent cells (i.e., regions need not be contiguous). Non-short-circuit-region areas should be stored as NODATA values. The file must have the same cell size and extent as the resistance grid. The parameter name in the config file for this option is 'polygon_file'.

precision.name: Precision
precision.description: Single or double precision? Single saves time and space but is less accurate.

profiler_log_file.name: Profiler log file
profiler_log_file.description: Path to log file for profiler

remove_src_or_gnd.name: Remove source or ground
remove_src_or_gnd.description: Remove source or ground? (currently not functioning)
remove_src_or_gnd.comment: there must be other values but I can't find them

set_focal_node_currents_to_zero.name: Set focal node currents to zero
set_focal_node_currents_to_zero.description: When running raster data in pairwise, all-to-one, and one-to all modes, focal nodes will have zero current in output maps when they are activated. For pairwise mode, cumulative maps will still show currents flowing through focal regions that results from other pairs being activated. This helps to show current flowing through a focal region as it moves between other focal regions in cumulative current maps. This current passing through a focal region can give an idea of the importance of the focal region for connecting other focal region pairs (for an example, see Fig. 5 in Dickson et al. 2013).

set_null_currents_to_nodata.name: Set null currents to nodata
set_null_currents_to_nodata.description: Set null currents to nodata (unknown functionality)

set_null_voltages_to_nodata.name: Set null voltages to nodata
set_null_voltages_to_nodata.description: Set null voltages to nodata (unknown functionality)

source_file.name: Source file
source_file.description: This file specifies locations and strengths, in amps, of current sources. Either a raster or a text list may be used. Rasters must have the same cell size, projection, and extent as the resistance grid, and cells that do not contain current sources should be coded with NODATA values. Note: current sources may be positive or negative (i.e., they may inject current into the grid or pull current out. Similarly, grounds may either serve as a sink for current or may contribute current if there are negative current sources in the grid).

use_direct_grounds.name: Use direct grounds
use_direct_grounds.description: Use direct connections to ground (R=0) for all ground points

use_included_pairs.name: Use included pairs
use_included_pairs.description: This option allows users to only perform calculations on a subset of focal node pairs. Users can either identify pairs to include in calculations, or pairs to exclude, as specified in the first line of the file. This affects all modes except the Advanced Mode. Files should be in tab-delimited text with a .txt extension.

use_mask.name: Use raster mask file
use_mask.description: Cells with negative, zero, or NODATA values in the mask will be dropped from the corresponding resistance map (i.e., treated as complete barriers). Positive integer cells will be retained. File should only contain integers and be in raster format.

use_polygons.name: Use short-circuit regions
use_polygons.description: Use short-circuit regions? In the config file, this is called 'use_polygons'.

use_unit_currents.name: Use unit currents
use_unit_currents.description: Use unit currents (i=1) for all current sources?

variable_source_file.name: Variable source strength file
variable_source_file.description: Path to variable source strength file

write_as_tif.name: Write outputs as TIFF files
write_as_tif.description: Write output as TIFF formatted file?
